abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews summer white wines from Spain, Chile and Burgundy; photo (M)

block.p: To imagine how the critic Harold Bloom, a famously omnivorous reader, might feel in Barnes & Noble, stroll into such richly stocked Westchester stores as Zachys and Rochambeau: so many wines, so little time. Even devotees of heavy fiction need light aperitif ''reads,'' like these summer whites.

Spain: Osborne Coquinero fino amontillado, an unusual sherry -- an aged fino -- of bracing dryness, with hints of almond. This pale, understated, entry-level aperitif, which doubles one's appetite, is $12 at Mamaroneck Station Liquors, 137 Halstead Avenue, Mamaroneck. (Imported by W. J. Deutsch & Sons in Harrison.)

Fino stales quickly. Insist on a recently delivered consignment, keep the wine iced and finish it in 10 days.

Think serrano ham or prosciutto, olives, nuts, seafood and Manchego cheese. The convivial English critic Hugh Johnson hits the bull's-eye: a glass of fino before or after gazpacho. (Two glasses, maximum, if you're driving afterward; the 17.5 percent alcohol is potent.)

Chile: The '98 Laura Hartwig chardonnay, a pretty, appley, to-the-point refresher from Santa Laura, a small producer, which has attracted favorable notices: $11 at Viscount, 1173 Route 9, Wappingers Falls. (Distributed by Jeroboam Wines, owned by Daniel Johnnes, wine director at Montrachet restaurant in Manhattan.)

Burgundy: The '98 Domaine de Champe Brule, a lovely, dry, fairly full-bodied Macon-Villages: $14 at Irvington Wines, 50 Main Street, Irvington. And a stylish, elegant '98 Pouilly-Fuisse: $17 at Varmax, 16 Putnam Avenue, Port Chester. (Both are Vincent Selections.)
